biogHist.abstract: Tardun Farm School was run by the Christian Brothers from 1928 as a Home where boys would learn farm skills. After World War II, Tardun housed British and Maltese child migrants aged from about 12 to 16 years as well as boys who were wards of state. Tardun Farm School closed in 1967 but remained open as an agricultural boarding school where some children were placed by the departments responsible for child welfare. Tardun closed at the end of 2008.
biogHist.p: Tardun Farm School was established by the Christian Brothers in 1928 as St Mary's Agricultural School.
The 'Tardun Agricultural College' was described in the Report of the Royal Commission on Youth Employment and the Apprenticeship System in 1938:

'The object of the school...is to recruit orphan boys from the Clontarf Orphanage at about the age of 12 to 15 years and give them a training in agricultural methods sufficient to enable them to conduct farming operations or to accept work as farm labourers. No fees are charged. The boys live on the farm. The idea is to select land and establish the most promising boys on their own farms. As regards the other boys, the Brothers place them in employment when they are ready, their wages ranging from 12s. 6d. To &pound2 10s. per week and keep. The school has initiated a system of instructing the boys in general educational subjects and putting them up for the Junior examination of the University - a policy to be recommended. The Principal of the school (Brother Conlon) states that there is no lack of application for the boys when they have finished their training. Report of the Royal Commissioner on Youth Employment and the Apprenticeship System, 1938, p.lxix'

The Royal Commissioner recommended (p.lxx) that the Government pay a maintenance allowance of 10 shillings per week for each 'destitute orphan boy' at Tardun provided the school undertook vocational and general education and training to the satisfaction of the Education Department. By 1940, this recommendation had not been implemented.

After World War II, Tardun admitted boys from various backgrounds including Wards of the State, child migrants, orphans and private admissions. Australian-born boys, and British and Maltese child migrants aged from about 12 to 16 years lived at Tardun. In 1967, the Farm School became an agricultural boarding and day school, which operated on the site until the end of 2008. Some children continued to be placed at Tardun by the departments responsible for child welfare.

The Christian Brothers' institutions Bindoon, Clontarf, Castledare and Tardun first received widespread publicity about child abuse in the early 1990s. In 1993, the Christian Brothers in Western Australia issued an apology and from 1995 have funded independent services to help with family tracing, counselling and remedial education for men who had suffered in their institutions. Many former residents of these institutions have shared their experiences and memories (bad and good) at government inquiries, in books and in oral histories.

chronItem.event: Location - Tardun Farm School was located at Tardun

descriptiveNote.p: It was not unusual for boys to be transferred between Tardun Farm School and Clontarf. In 1942, boys were evacuated to Tardun from Clontarf, at the request of the defence forces.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Castledare (1934 - 1983)

descriptiveNote.p: Boys often went to Tardun from Castledare.
It was not unusual for boys to be transferred between Bindoon and Tardun Farm School.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Royal Commission on Youth Employment and the Apprenticeship System, State of Western Australia (1937 - 1938)

descriptiveNote.p: Tardun Farm School (Tardun Agricultural College) was reviewed by the Royal Commission on Youth Employment and the Apprenticeship System.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Presentation Sisters, Society of Australian Congregations of the Presentation of the Blessed Virgin Mary

descriptiveNote.p: The Presentation Sisters had a working community at Tardun.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Royal Commission appointed to Inquire into the Care and Reform of Youthful Delinquents, State of Western Australia (1943)

descriptiveNote.p: Tardun was used to confine boys who had been convicted of offences by the Children's Court, according to evidence given in the Royal Commission appointed to Inquire into the Care and Reform of Youthful Delinquents.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Juvenile Offending (1840s - )

descriptiveNote.p: Some boys were admitted toTardun Farm School because they had been involved in what authorities deemed juvenile offending.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Father Hudson's Society, United Kingdom (1902 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Father Hudson's Society was one of the Homes in Britain that sent children to Tardun Farm School.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association [CEMWA] (1947? - 1970)

descriptiveNote.p: The Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association [CEMWA] coordinated the placement of chlild migrants to Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association [CEMWA].

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Catholic Immigration Scheme (1947 - 1966)

descriptiveNote.p: Tardun Farm School was part of the Catholic Immigration Scheme that sent children from Britain and Malta to Western Australia.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Ross Fact-Finding Mission [British child migration] (1956)

descriptiveNote.p: The Ross Fact-Finding Mission [British child migration] was was interested in the welfare of British child migrants sent to Tardun Farm School.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: The Christian Brothers' Agricultural School, Tardun, Western Australia

archref.unittitle: The Christian Brothers' Agricultural School, Tardun, Western Australia
archref.abstract:
'The Christian Brothers' Agricultural School Tardun Western Australia' is a digital copy of a booklet held by the Department of Communities. The booklet is undated but a handwritten note on the front cover is dated 1936. It appears to be a prospectus, written to advertise the perceived benefits of the 'Tardun Scheme' and attract donors. The 20-page booklet contains many photographs of boys and notable benefactors.
There is a detailed description of the education and training program at the Tardun Farm School, and the boys' progression from Castledare, to Clontarf and on to Tardun - including information about government subsidies and service wages.
Photographs include farm buildings and activities at Tardun, such as 'Benito Boy' (a prize stallion), the original buildings, first group of trainees at Tardun, and the dam.
There are also photographs of the Clontarf Band, manual arts room and beehives, and images of Castledare including Matron and boys, and scenes of the buildings.
archref.note: Reproduced with the kind permission of the Department of Communities, Western Australia

resourceRelation.relationEntry: CEMWA Response to Moss Questionnaire

archref.abstract: 'CEMWA Response to Moss Questionnaire' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. There is an undated letter from the Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association Inc, responding to questions about Bindoon, Clontarf, Castledare,Nazareth House, St Joseph's Orphanage (including St Vincent's Foundling Home), and Tardun. There is also a letter, dated 14 August 1951, from the Under Secretary for Lands and Immigration passing on further information about staffing at those institutions.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia

archref.unittitle: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia
archref.abstract: 'Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It is the questionnaire that was circulated to government, the organisations that received and placed child migrants, and the children's Homes where the children lived. This questionnaire was received by the Commonwealth Government on 10 May 1951.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Tardun Slideshow, Part 1

archref.repository: Christian Brothers Institution Albums 1 & 2 (Holy Spirit Collection)
archref.abstract:
This is Part 1 of a slideshow of photographs from the archives of the Christian Brothers Oceania Province. It was created by 'old boys' Peter Bent and Michael Hogan, with assistance from Ed Butler, using images from 'Institution Albums 1 and 2'. There are all sorts of scenes from life at Tardun from the 1940s to 1960s. Many people assisted with the identification of boys, brothers and staff to create captions for the images in this slideshow. DVD copies of this slideshow are available from Tuart Place.
The Find & Connect website has split the slideshow into two parts so that it could be uploaded onto youtube. Please click on the photo, which will take you to youtube.

descriptiveNote.p: Include in Gallery

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Farm Schools

archref.abstract: 'Farm Schools' is an excerpt from the Report of the Royal Commission on Youth Employment and the Apprenticeship System which is held online by the Parliament of Western Australia. It gives an overview of the four Farm Schools operating in WA in 1938: Fairbridge Farm School; Tardun Agricultural College; Werribee Boys' Home; and the Unemployed Boys' Farm at Wokalup. The full Report is very large and difficult to download, so this relevant excerpt has been reproduced for quick downloading from the Find & Connect web resource.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II

archref.unittitle: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II
archref.abstract: This is a file held online by the National Archives of Australia. It has draft reports on the Australian institutions which took unaccompanied British child migrants after World War Two.

archref.repository: Christian Brothers Institution Albums 1 & 2 (Holy Spirit Collection)

This is Part 2 of a slideshow of photographs from the archives of the Christian Brothers Oceania Province. It was created by 'old boys' Peter Bent and Michael Hogan, with assistance from Ed Butler, using images from 'Institution Albums 1 and 2'. There are all sorts of scenes from life at Tardun from the 1940s to 1960s. Many people assisted with the identification of boys, brothers and staff to create captions for the images in this slideshow. DVD copies of this slideshow are available from Tuart Place.
The Find & Connect website has split the slideshow into two parts so that it could be uploaded onto youtube. Please click on the photo, which will take you to youtube.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Enduring Struggle

archref.abstract: Enduring Struggle is the title of a book by former child migrant and academic, Professor David Plowman. This is a photo of the cover page, showing the chapel and main building at St Mary's Agricultural Farm School, Tardun.
